title: Tteokbokki (Spicy Rice Cakes)
description: A classic Korean street-food dish of chewy rice cakes simmered in a savory-spicy gochujang-based sauce with fish cake and scallions. Rich, slightly sweet, and umami-forward, it's quick to prepare on the stovetop and perfect as a snack or casual meal.

ingredients.display_name: Korean rice cakes (garaetteok), refrigerated or frozen
ingredients.notes: If frozen, thaw under cold running water for a few minutes; separate pieces

ingredients.display_name: Water (for simmer/broth) or light anchovy broth
ingredients.notes: Use water or homemade anchovy-kelp broth for more umami
Adjust to taste for heat and depth

ingredients.display_name: Gochugaru (Korean chili flakes), optional for extra heat
Korean fish cake (eomuk), sliced into strips
Scallions, trimmed and cut into 2-3 inch pieces

ingredients.notes: Traditional garnish; can be omitted for vegetarian

ingredients.display_name: Neutral oil (vegetable or canola) for sautéing

steps.text: If using refrigerated rice cakes, separate pieces. If frozen, rinse under cold running water until pliable. Drain and set aside.
In a wide shallow pan or skillet, bring the water or anchovy broth to a gentle boil over medium-high heat.
Add gochujang, gochugaru (if using), soy sauce, sugar, and minced garlic to the simmering liquid; whisk or stir until the paste dissolves and the sauce is smooth.
Add the rice cakes to the simmering sauce, distributing them in a single layer as much as possible. Reduce heat to medium-low to maintain a gentle simmer.

Simmer, stirring gently every 1–2 minutes to prevent sticking, until rice cakes are soft and sauce thickens and reduces to a glossy coating (sauce should cling to rice cakes). This typically takes 8–10 minutes; add a splash of water if the mixture becomes too dry before rice cakes are tender.
About halfway through the simmer, add sliced fish cake and sliced onion to warm through and absorb the sauce.
When rice cakes are tender and sauce is reduced to desired thickness, stir in scallions and sesame oil, then remove from heat. If using, nestle peeled hard-boiled eggs into the pan to warm briefly.
Transfer to serving bowls, sprinkle with toasted sesame seeds and reserved scallion, and serve immediately while hot and saucy.
